question: In column liquid chromatography the eluant strength or elution power of a mobile phase is of great importance. In this context:
correct_answer: A solvent B will have a greater eluent strength than another A if a solute has a lower retention factor in the same column when B is used as a mobile phase than when A is used.
options: A)In a mobile phase formed by a mixture of water and an organic modifier (reverse phase chromatography), the lower the modifier content, the higher its eluent strength.
B)A solvent B will have a greater eluent strength than another A if a solute has a lower retention factor in the same column when B is used as a mobile phase than when A is used.
C)Eluents are classified as strong and weak, depending on whether their eluent strength is low or high, respectively.
D)In reverse phase liquid chromatography, any organic modifier is a weak solvent compared to water.
prompt:
In column liquid chromatography the eluant strength or elution power of a mobile phase is of great importance. In this context:A)In a mobile phase formed by a mixture of water and an organic modifier (reverse phase chromatography), the lower the modifier content, the higher its eluent strength.
B)A solvent B will have a greater eluent strength than another A if a solute has a lower retention factor in the same column when B is used as a mobile phase than when A is used.
C)Eluents are classified as strong and weak, depending on whether their eluent strength is low or high, respectively.
D)In reverse phase liquid chromatography, any organic modifier is a weak solvent compared to water.
output0: The eluent strength of a mobile phase in reverse phase liquid chromatography is determined by the ratio of the organic modifier to water. A lower modifier content results in a higher eluent strength, as the organic modifier is the weaker component.
output1: This is because the eluent strength of a mobile phase is determined by the ability of the solvent to dissolve the solute and carry it through the column. If a solute has a lower retention factor in a particular mobile phase, it means that it is more easily dissolved and carried through the column by that solvent. Therefore, a solvent with a lower retention factor will have a greater eluent strength than a solvent with a higher retention factor.
output2: Eluents are classified as strong or weak based on their eluent strength, which is a measure of the ability of the mobile phase to dissolve and separate the analytes in the column. Strong eluents have high eluent strength and can dissolve and separate the analytes more easily, while weak eluents have low eluent strength and may not be able to dissolve and separate the analytes as effectively.
output3: In reverse phase liquid chromatography, the mobile phase is a mixture of water and an organic modifier. The organic modifier is a weak solvent compared to water, which means that it will have a lower eluent strength. This is because the organic modifier will have a lower affinity for the analytes being separated, resulting in a lower retention factor for the analytes.

question: A 75-year-old man comes to the physician for the evaluation of progressive shortness of breath and fatigue over the past month. He reports that he cannot climb more than one flight of stairs without experiencing shortness of breath and dizziness. He has hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 50 years. He does not drink alcohol. His medications include enalapril, atorvastatin, and low-dose aspirin. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 70/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 100/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows weak peripheral pulses. Cardiac examination is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
prompt:
A 75-year-old man comes to the physician for the evaluation of progressive shortness of breath and fatigue over the past month. He reports that he cannot climb more than one flight of stairs without experiencing shortness of breath and dizziness. He has hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 50 years. He does not drink alcohol. His medications include enalapril, atorvastatin, and low-dose aspirin. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 70/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 100/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows weak peripheral pulses. Cardiac examination is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?A)Tricuspid valve stenosis
B)Mitral valve prolapse
C)Mitral valve stenosis
D)Aortic valve stenosis
output0: The most likely diagnosis is tricuspid valve stenosis based on the patient's symptoms of shortness of breath and fatigue, as well as the physical examination findings of weak peripheral pulses.
output1: The most likely diagnosis is mitral valve prolapse (MVP) based on the patient's symptoms of shortness of breath and fatigue, as well as the physical examination findings of weak peripheral pulses and a cardiac murmur. MVP is a common condition in which the mitral valve does not close properly, leading to regurgitation of blood into the left atrium and ventricle. The patient's history of smoking and hypertension may have contributed to the development of this condition.
output2: The patient's symptoms of progressive shortness of breath and fatigue, along with the physical examination findings of weak peripheral pulses, suggest a cardiac condition. The patient's history of smoking and hypertension also increase the likelihood of a cardiac diagnosis. Of the options provided, the most likely diagnosis is mitral valve stenosis, which is a common condition in older adults and can cause shortness of breath, fatigue, and weak peripheral pulses.
output3: Aortic valve stenosis is the most likely diagnosis based on the patient's symptoms of shortness of breath and fatigue, which are consistent with decreased cardiac output due to aortic valve obstruction. The patient's history of smoking and hypertension also increase the likelihood of aortic valve disease. Additionally, the patient's weak peripheral pulses and normal cardiac examination findings are consistent with aortic valve stenosis.

question: Which of the following antiarrhythmic drugs can produce thyroid alterations as an adverse effect ?:
prompt:
Which of the following antiarrhythmic drugs can produce thyroid alterations as an adverse effect ?:A)Vernakalant.
B)Amiodarone
C)Lidocaine
D)Diltiazem.
output0: Vernakalant is an antiarrhythmic drug that can produce thyroid alterations as an adverse effect. Specifically, it can cause hypothyroidism (an underactive thyroid gland) and thyrotoxicosis (an overactive thyroid gland).
output1: Amiodarone is an antiarrhythmic drug that can cause thyroid alterations as an adverse effect. Specifically, it can cause thyrotoxicosis (an overactive thyroid gland) or hypothyroidism (an underactive thyroid gland).
output2: Lidocaine is an antiarrhythmic drug that can produce thyroid alterations as an adverse effect. Specifically, it can cause hypothyroidism, which is a condition where the thyroid gland does not produce enough thyroid hormones. This can lead to a range of symptoms, including weight gain, fatigue, and depression.
output3: Diltiazem is an antiarrhythmic drug that can cause thyroid alterations as an adverse effect. Specifically, it can cause thyroid nodules and goiter. The other options, Vernakalant, Amiodarone, and Lidocaine, are not associated with thyroid alterations as adverse effects.

question: Class 3 hemorrhagic shock refers to:
prompt:
Class 3 hemorrhagic shock refers to:A)Blood loss less than 15 %
B)Blood loss between 15 % - 30%
C)Blood loss between 30% - 40%
D)Blood loss more than 40%
output0: Class 3 hemorrhagic shock refers to blood loss less than 15% of the total blood volume. This is considered a moderate level of blood loss and may require medical intervention to prevent further complications.
output1: Class 3 hemorrhagic shock refers to blood loss between 15% - 30% of the total blood volume. This type of shock is characterized by a decrease in blood pressure and cardiac output, and can be accompanied by symptoms such as dizziness, confusion, and decreased urine output.
output2: Class 3 hemorrhagic shock refers to a moderate level of blood loss, which can be defined as a loss of 30-40% of the child's total blood volume. This level of blood loss can be associated with significant symptoms, such as tachycardia, tachypnea, and decreased consciousness.
output3: Class 3 hemorrhagic shock refers to blood loss of more than 40% of the total blood volume. This is a severe form of hemorrhage that can be life-threatening and requires immediate medical attention.

question: Which of the following is a major component of the habit inversion technique for simple tics ?:
correct_answer: The practice of an incompatible or competitive response to its appearance.
options: A)The positive reinforcement of the child's efforts to inhibit tic.
B)The practice of an incompatible or competitive response to its appearance.
C)The combined use of operant procedures with psychotropic drugs.
prompt:
Which of the following is a major component of the habit inversion technique for simple tics ?:A)The positive reinforcement of the child's efforts to inhibit tic.
B)The practice of an incompatible or competitive response to its appearance.
C)The combined use of operant procedures with psychotropic drugs.
D)The contingent negative practice.
output0: The habit inversion technique for simple tics involves the use of positive reinforcement to encourage the child to inhibit the tic. This is done by rewarding the child for successfully inhibiting the tic, which helps to strengthen the child's ability to control the tic.
output1: The habit inversion technique for simple tics involves the practice of an incompatible or competitive response to the appearance of the tic. This technique is based on the idea that the child can learn to inhibit the tic by performing a behavior that is incompatible with the tic.
output2: The habit inversion technique for simple tics involves the combined use of operant procedures, such as reinforcement and punishment, with psychotropic drugs to help inhibit the tic. This is a major component of the technique.
output3: The Habit Inversion Technique for simple tics involves the use of a contingent negative practice, which means that the child is rewarded for not performing the tic. This approach is based on the idea that the child will learn to associate the absence of the tic with a positive outcome, leading to the reduction or elimination of the tic.

question: An 18 years old girl presents with primary amenorrhea. On evaluation, she was having a karyotype of 45X0 and infantile uterus. What should he done next?
prompt:
An 18 years old girl presents with primary amenorrhea. On evaluation, she was having a karyotype of 45X0 and infantile uterus. What should he done next?A)H to induce pubey
B)Vaginoplasty
C)Clitoroplasty
D)Bilateral gonadectomy
output0: The patient has a karyotype of 45X0, which is a chromosomal abnormality that can result in a variety of developmental and reproductive issues. In this case, the patient has primary amenorrhea and an infantile uterus, which suggests that she may have a congenital defect that is preventing her from developing normally. The best course of action would be to induce puberty with hormone replacement therapy to help her body develop normally.
output1: Vaginoplasty is the appropriate next step in this case, as the patient has a congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) and a virilized phenotype, and she has not yet reached puberty. Vaginoplasty can help to create a functional vagina and improve the patient's quality of life.
output2: The correct answer is Clitoroplasty because the patient has a 45X0 karyotype, which is a Turner Syndrome. This condition is characterized by a missing or incomplete X chromosome, which can result in a variety of physical and developmental abnormalities, including primary amenorrhea. Clitoroplasty is a surgical procedure that can help to improve the appearance of the clitoris and to provide sexual satisfaction.
output3: The patient's karyotype of 45X0 indicates a Turner Syndrome, which is characterized by monosomy of the X chromosome. This condition is associated with primary amenorrhea, infantile uterus, and other reproductive abnormalities. The most appropriate management for this patient would be bilateral gonadectomy, which involves the removal of both ovaries and testes. This will prevent any further development of the gonads and reduce the risk of malignancy.

question: Margin under the domination of muscle (inferior gemellus) of nerve damage, which of the following may atrophy?
prompt:
Margin under the domination of muscle (inferior gemellus) of nerve damage, which of the following may atrophy?A)The margin muscles (superior gemellus)
B)Piriformis (piriformis)
C)Stock side muscle (quadratus femoris)
D)Obturator muscle (obturator internus)
output0: If there is nerve damage to the inferior gemellus, the superior gemellus muscle may atrophy due to the dominant effect of the inferior gemellus.
output1: The piriformis muscle is a flat, band-like muscle that runs from the base of the spine to the thigh bone (femur). It plays a crucial role in maintaining the position of the foot and ankle during movement. If the margin of the inferior gemellus is damaged, it can cause weakness or paralysis of the piriformis muscle, leading to atrophy.
output2: If there is nerve damage to the inferior gemellus, the muscle may become atrophic. This can lead to a weakness in the stock side muscle (quadratus femoris), which is the muscle that is responsible for the external rotation of the hip joint.
output3: If there is nerve damage to the inferior gemellus, the obturator muscle may atrophy due to the loss of innervation. The obturator muscle is a deep muscle in the lower extremity that plays a critical role in hip and knee movement.

question: on examination 18 month old child has inward detion of both eyes, which of the following test should be done?
prompt:
on examination 18 month old child has inward detion of both eyes, which of the following test should be done?A)Forced duction test
B)Cover Uncover Test
C)Fundus Examination
D)All of the above
output0: The Forced Dution Test is the most appropriate test to perform on an 18-month-old child with an inward detention of both eyes. This test is used to assess the child's ability to align their eyes and to detect any signs of strabismus (crossed eyes).
output1: The Cover Uncover Test is the most appropriate test to assess the ability of an 18-month-old child to control their eye movements. This test is used to evaluate the child's ability to track and fixate objects, and to assess the alignment of the eyes.
output2: A fundus examination is necessary to assess the retina and optic nerve head in a child with inward detention of both eyes. The other options are not necessary for this condition.
output3: All of the above tests are appropriate for assessing the inward detention of both eyes in an 18-month-old child. The forced duction test is used to assess the range of motion of the eyes and the cover uncover test is used to assess the alignment of the eyes. The fundus examination is used to assess the health of the retina and optic nerve.

question: The following statements about phenylketonuria (Phenylketonuria), and what's right?
correct_answer: A typical phenylketonuria patients, appears developmental delay, vomiting, symptoms such as skin and hair color fades
options: A)Autosomal dominant inheritance pattern is mainly Phenylalanine hydroxylase (PAH) or Tetrahydrobiopterin (BH4) defect of the
B)A typical phenylketonuria patients, appears developmental delay, vomiting, symptoms such as skin and hair color fades
C)To avoid intellectual impairment, need to limit phenylalanine (Phenylalanine) feeding, it is recommended to maintain blood phenylalanine 2 mg / dL or less in
D)Fertility of the female phenylketonuria (Phenylketonuria) patients, should be strictly controlled blood phenylalanine (Phenylalanine) concentrations to
prompt:
The following statements about phenylketonuria (Phenylketonuria), and what's right?A)Autosomal dominant inheritance pattern is mainly Phenylalanine hydroxylase (PAH) or Tetrahydrobiopterin (BH4) defect of the
B)A typical phenylketonuria patients, appears developmental delay, vomiting, symptoms such as skin and hair color fades
C)To avoid intellectual impairment, need to limit phenylalanine (Phenylalanine) feeding, it is recommended to maintain blood phenylalanine 2 mg / dL or less in
D)Fertility of the female phenylketonuria (Phenylketonuria) patients, should be strictly controlled blood phenylalanine (Phenylalanine) concentrations to
output0: The correct answer is A)Autosomal dominant inheritance pattern is mainly Phenylalanine hydroxylase (PAH) or Tetrahydrobiopterin (BH4) defect of the. This is because phenylketonuria (Phenylketonuria) is a genetic disorder caused by a defect in the gene that codes for the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase (PAH). This enzyme is responsible for converting the amino acid phenylalanine (Phenylalanine) into tyrosine (Tyrosine). When the PAH enzyme is defective, phenylalanine (Phenylalanine) builds up in the blood and can cause a range of symptoms, including developmental delay, vomiting, and skin and hair color changes.
output1: The correct answer is B)A typical phenylketonuria patients, appears developmental delay, vomiting, symptoms such as skin and hair color fades, because these symptoms are common in phenylketonuria patients, which is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by a defect in the gene that codes for the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase (PAH). This enzyme is necessary for the breakdown of the amino acid phenylalanine, and without it, phenylalanine builds up in the blood and brain, leading to the symptoms mentioned.
output2: The correct answer is C)To avoid intellectual impairment, need to limit phenylalanine (Phenylalanine) feeding, it is recommended to maintain blood phenylalanine 2 mg / dL or less in, because phenylalanine (Phenylalanine) is an essential amino acid, it is necessary to maintain a certain level of phenylalanine in the blood to avoid intellectual impairment, so the dietary restriction of phenylalanine (Phenylalanine) is necessary to prevent intellectual impairment in phenylketonuria (Phenylketonuria) patients.
output3: Female phenylketonuria (Phenylketonuria) patients are at risk of having children with the condition, as the disorder is autosomal dominant. To avoid passing the condition on to their offspring, it is important to strictly control blood phenylalanine (Phenylalanine) concentrations in females with phenylketonuria (Phenylketonuria).

question: A person because of stomach pain and seek treatment, endoscopic examination revealed a gastric ulcer, stomach sliced ​​through the mining test and found to Helicobacter pylori infection, so doctors prescribed three antibiotics to a patient, one is clarithromycin. This principal mechanism of action of antibiotics Why?
correct_answer: Inhibition of protein synthesis of the bacteria
options: A)The bacteria cell wall synthesis inhibition
B)Inhibition of the synthesis of nucleic acid bacteria
C)Inhibition of protein synthesis of the bacteria
D)Inhibition of the synthesis of the cell membrane bacteria
prompt:
A person because of stomach pain and seek treatment, endoscopic examination revealed a gastric ulcer, stomach sliced ​​through the mining test and found to Helicobacter pylori infection, so doctors prescribed three antibiotics to a patient, one is clarithromycin. This principal mechanism of action of antibiotics Why?A)The bacteria cell wall synthesis inhibition
B)Inhibition of the synthesis of nucleic acid bacteria
C)Inhibition of protein synthesis of the bacteria
D)Inhibition of the synthesis of the cell membrane bacteria
output0: The bacteria Helicobacter pylori has a unique cell wall synthesis mechanism, which is inhibited by clarithromycin, leading to the death of the bacteria.
output1: Clarithromycin, a macrolide antibiotic, inhibits the synthesis of nucleic acids, specifically DNA and RNA, which are essential for the growth and reproduction of bacteria, including Helicobacter pylori. This is the main mechanism of action of clarithromycin in treating gastric ulcers caused by H. pylori infection.
output2: Clarithromycin works by inhibiting protein synthesis of the bacteria, which is the principal mechanism of action of this antibiotic against Helicobacter pylori.
output3: Clarithromycin, an antibiotic commonly used to treat Helicobacter pylori infections, works by inhibiting the synthesis of the cell membrane of the bacteria. This prevents the bacteria from being able to maintain their structural integrity and ultimately leads to their death.
